conclusion: Treat A + B as a single system to find the common acceleration that the applied force can cause before either interface starts sliding.
Check the maximum horizontal force that static friction can transmit at the A–B interface (given as 1 N).
Compare the horizontal inertial (m a) demand on block A with that maximum static friction.
Check that the force the ground can oppose on block B (kinetic-friction coefficient 0.10 times its normal force) is not exceeded while the two blocks are still moving together.
Combine those conditions to find the greatest F that satisfies both.
Condition from A not sliding on B: F ≤ 3 N.
Condition from B not breaking the available ground friction while dragging A along: F ≤ 3.9 N.
